results.title: The Work That Was. Parts 1 & 2
results.brief_description: Who Pays the Price? (Sydney, 1979, 30 min.): Looks at the possible social effects of technological change in the context of Australia’s economic system. “Futures” (Sydney, 1979, 30 min.): Looks at the decline of labour intensive manufacturing industries in Australia, unemployment in country towns, and the prospects of the coming mineral boom.

results.title: Childhood memories of Fitzroy
results.creator_credit: Deborah Deacon, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a tribute to her mother, the Indigenous activist Eleanor Harding, Deborah Deacon tells of her life and various struggles. Wanting a better life for her family was the main motivation in Eleanor moving from her home in Queensland to Melbourne. She eventually found a community in Fitzroy who supported her when she needed it at the start. Eleanor never forgot this, and devoted her life to helping out the community in various ways throughout her life. Her mother, as well as the elders of her community, have instilled in Deborah a strong sense of both individual and community empowerment.

results.title: The Thin red line [1964]
results.creator_credit: Andrew Marton, Sidney Harmon and Ace Films
results.brief_description: There’s a thin red line between the sane and the mad, or so goes the saying. These sentiments weigh heavily on Private Doll, facing the horrors of war for the first time. Having left behind his wife of just eight days, Doll is determined to do whatever it is required to stay alive and to maintain his sanity. As he battles Japanese soldiers however, he is also engaged in a battle with one of his own, a sadistic and tough Sergeant (Jack Warden), who is starkly contrasted to the thoughtful Doll. This explosive dramatization of the American assault on Guadalcanal in World War 2 is a thoughtful study on the effects of war on innocent and not so innocent minds, and the apparent meaninglessness of it all. Cast includes Keir Dullea and Jack Warden. Based on the novel by James Jones.

results.title: The Thin red line (Malick)
results.creator_credit: Terrence Malick, John Roberdeau, Robert Michael Geisler and Phoenix Pictures
results.brief_description: Based on James Jones’ tough, autobiographical novel about a group of young soldiers landing at Guadalcanal Island to fight the Japanese, Terrence Malick’s “The Thin Red Line” stands comparison with the greatest of war movies. The narrative shifts from Private to General, from Lieutenant to Seargent, a continuous fragmented voice-over in which the audience is made to confront the fears and terrors that every soldier must face in battle. Malick contrasts the lush savage beauty of the Solomon Islands with the glistening weapons of war brought in by the Americans and the Japanese, and the film moves from becoming the story of a battle to becoming a tragically moving anti-war epic. That Malick is able to see the suffering and humiliation of war and defeat, while making a film about one of the most successful American campaigns in World War II history, is a testament to his commitment to universalist humanist values. The outstanding musical score, blending classical, western and Polynesian music, is by Hans Zimmer; the ravishing cinematography is by John Toll. In a cast distinguished by fine ensemble playing, Sean Penn, Jim Caviezel, Nick Nolte and Elias Koteas are outstanding. Winner of the Golden Bear at the Berlin Film Festival and nominated for 7 Academy Awards (it lost out to “Saving Private Ryan”).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Terrence Malick, John Roberdeau, Robert Michael Geisler and Phoenix Pictures

results.title: Doing it our way, according to our culture
results.creator_credit: Frances Gallagher, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Growing up in a mission, Frances Gallagher had disjointed access to her own culture and found it hard to navigate the world outside. By looking into her past, and through her years of community work, Frances sends a strong message of the importance of empowerment and self-determination. Essentially, a community is much stronger when they can manage their own affairs, their way and according to their culture and beliefs.

results.title: The Thin man
results.creator_credit: W S. Van Dyke, Hunt Stromberg, Cosmopolitan and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Dashiell Hammett’s 1932 detective novel, “The thin man”, was a best- seller sought by every major Hollywood studio. MGM won out and the result is a crime thriller combined with high comedy. As Nick and Nora Charles, the wisecracking darlings of society, William Powell and Myrna Loy made history portraying two sophisticates who are not only married but also very much in love, also stars Cesar Romero.
results.creator_credit_for_label: W S. Van Dyke, Hunt Stromberg, Cosmopolitan and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer

results.title: The Thieving magpie = La Gazza ladra
results.creator_credit: Giulio Gianini, Emanuele Luzzati and Universal Education and Visual Arts
results.brief_description: An Italian cartoon based on an original fairy tale, inspired by Rossini’s lively overture, La Gazza Ladra (The Thieving Magpie), and by the personality of a pet magpie that had lived in the Gianini home for many years. The cartoon depicts a pageant of medieval knights whose grand procession is reduced to havoc by one insolent bird who would rather steal crowns than dodge arrows. No commentary, music only.

results.title: Victimised, Assimalised, Correctionalised
results.creator_credit: Howard Edwards, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: As a child, Howard Edwards was shunted from orphanage to orphanage. Made a ward of the state in 1956, he was abused and beaten wherever he was sent. His incarceration didn’t end there and for much of his adult life Howard was a target for police and he was often locked up at the slightest provocation. A large part of Howard’s journey towards healing involved reconnecting with his family, his work in the community and on the board of the Aboriginal Health Care Service.

results.title: The Thief of Baghdad
results.creator_credit: Raoul Walsh, Douglas Fairbanks and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Douglas Fairbanks plays the part of the Thief of Bagdad. He tries to win the heart of his true love, the Caliph’s daughter, by competing with various Princes to find rare treasure.

constellations_other.name: Right on cue
constellations_other.description: In the silent film era, cue sheets charted major moments of a film, along with recommended audio accompaniment matching the action on screen.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Raoul Walsh, Douglas Fairbanks and United Artists Corporation
results.description: Douglas Fairbanks plays the part of the Thief of Bagdad. He tries to win the heart of his true love, the Caliph’s daughter, by competing with various Princes to find rare treasure. He climbs clouds, battles sea-creatures and killer plants, defeats the Mongols with an army of dust, rides a winged horse and finally becomes victorious. This silent classic is a much loved children’s film.
description_for_label: Douglas Fairbanks plays the part of the Thief of Bagdad. He tries to win the heart of his true love, the Caliph’s daughter, by competing with various Princes to find rare treasure. He climbs clouds, battles sea-creatures and killer plants, defeats the Mongols with an army of dust, rides a winged horse and finally becomes victorious. This silent classic is a much loved children’s film.

results.title: Growing up in Fitzroy
results.creator_credit: Marlene Scerri, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Marlene (Scerri) Young gives us a picture of what it was like to grow up in Fitzroy in the 1950s. She lovingly tells of the closeness to her extended family, the friends coming to stay over and the strong sense of community, especially the Christmas parades down Smith Street.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marlene Scerri, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
